question.text: Choose the correct sequence of biotic succession for hydrosere.

options.text: Phytoplankton <math><mo>→</mo></math> Floating stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math> Submerged stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Sedges  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Reed swamp stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>    Bushes  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Bushes  <math><mo>→</mo></math> Trees

Zooplankton  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Floating stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Submerged stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Reed swamp stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Sedges  <math><mo>→</mo></math>   Bushes  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Trees

Phytoplankton <math><mo>→</mo></math> Zooplankton <math><mo>→</mo></math> Submerged stage <math><mo>→</mo></math> Floating stage <math><mo>→</mo></math> Reed swamp stage <math><mo>→</mo></math> Sedges <math><mo>→</mo></math> Bushes <math><mo>→</mo></math> Trees

Zooplankon  <math><mo>→</mo></math> Submerged stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Floating stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Sedges  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Reed swamp stage  <math><mo>→</mo></math>     Bushes  <math><mo>→</mo></math>  Trees

solution.text:
Hydrosere is the series of biotic communities that form/develop in a newly formed aquatic system like a lake or pond.

Hydrosere has several stages of succession as below -

Phytoplanktons (producers) → zooplanktons (consumer) → rooted submerged hydrophytes → free-floating hydrophytes → reed swamps → sedges or marsh-meadow stage → woodland or scrub stage → trees (climax forest).
